scenes.narrative: The cellar beneath the Dorset Street printshop is lit by a single oil lamp. The man you have been hunting — a former Scotland Yard clerk named Aldgate, now in the employ of someone far above him — stands at the far end with a revolver and the look of a man who has run out of options. The cipher notes are stacked on a workbench beside him. Three murders. A cover-up that reaches to the Deputy Commissioner. And you, alone, in a cellar that smells of ink and old fear. How you end this is up to you.

choices.text: Rush him before he can fire — close the distance and end this with your hands.
Talk him down — he is a frightened man, not a true believer. Give him a way out.
There is a passage behind the shelves. The symbols on the wall are glowing faintly. Follow them.

scenes.narrative: The passage opens into a vaulted chamber beneath the printshop. The air is thick with the smell of old incense and something else — something that prickles at the edge of perception. The symbols carved into the walls are not merely decorative. They pulse with a cold, grey light, and the shadows between them move with a purpose that has nothing to do with the guttering lamp in your hand. Something is here. Something that was summoned and never properly dismissed.

choices.text: Recite the Grey Dawn's dismissal ward — the primer described the counter-sigil.
Stand your ground. Do not look away. Do not flinch.
Retreat back through the passage. This is beyond your remit.
Search for the binding circle's anchor point — there must be a physical focus.
Flee. Whatever this is, it is not worth your life.

scenes.narrative: The revolver fires wide as you close the distance. The struggle is brief and brutal. Aldgate goes down hard, and the cipher notes scatter across the cellar floor. When Inspector Graves arrives — summoned by the shot — he finds you standing over a bound and bleeding man, surrounded by evidence of three murders and a conspiracy that reaches to the highest levels of Scotland Yard. Graves looks at the evidence. He looks at you. Then, slowly, he begins to take notes. The Deputy Commissioner will not sleep well tonight.

You speak quietly and precisely. You tell Aldgate what you know, what you can prove, and — crucially — what you are willing to offer: testimony that he cooperated, that he was coerced, that the real villain sits behind a desk in Scotland Yard. The revolver lowers by degrees. When Graves arrives, Aldgate is sitting on the floor with his hands on his knees, ready to talk. The Deputy Commissioner's name is in the first sentence. The case unravels upward from there, and the Rationalists' Circle finds itself with a very uncomfortable question to answer.

onEnter.target: Hermetic Order of the Grey Dawn
